titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

div.p: If a great change is to be made in human affairs, the minds of men will be fitted to it, the general opinions and feelings will draw that way. Every fear, every hope will forward it; and then they who persist in opposing this mighty current in human affairs will appear rather to resist the decrees of Providence itself than the mere designs of men. They will not be resolute and firm, but perverse and obstinate.

body.p: I finished and despatched an article on 'Tennessee' for the Evening Standard. The conclusion of the laughable farce of the trial at Dayton is announced today. The school teacher, Scopes, is of course condemned, & fined 100 dollars!

After lunch I motored to Durham, & had a consultation with the Bishop of Jarrow about the vacant benefices. Then I had an interview with Wallis, & arranged that Jimmie should go there next term. After tea with Cruickshank I returned to Auckland. Almost immediately the crank, Lomax, from Ferryhill appeared, and blathered for nearly an hour! I wrote to George Adam Smith asking him to come, & address the clergy.
